Why is this plane perpendicular to n?
A point (x,y,z) belongs to the given plane exactly when its position vector \Vect{x} = (x,y,z) is perpendicular to \Vect{n} = ({\color{red} 2},{\color{red} 9},{\color{red} -3}). This happens exactly when
0 = \DotPr{ \Vect{n} }{ \Vect{x} } = \DotPr{ ({\color{red} 2},{\color{red} 9},{\color{red} -3}) }{ (x,y,z) } = {\color{red} 2}x + {\color{red} 9}y {\color{red} -3}z
to the vector \Vect{n} = ({\color{red} 2},{\color{red} 9},{\color{red} -3}). This plane is an example of a hyperspace in \RNr[3].
